hedline.hl1: With Great, Uh, Fanfare The Borgata Opens

abstract.p: Actor Stephen Dorff, who played minor character in early 1990's sitcom Blossom and actor Joe Pantoliano, who played in Sopranos before his character was killed off last season, help open Borgata Hotel Casino and Spa in Atlantic City; photo (M)

block.p: If you build it, the celebrities will come. In theory.
But that was not necessarily the case on Wednesday night as the Borgata Hotel Casino and Spa primped for its long-awaited opening.
If you build it, the celebrities will come. In theory.
But that was not necessarily the case on Wednesday night as the Borgata Hotel Casino and Spa primped for its long-awaited opening.
Yes, there were the limber bartenders in the Gypsy Bar with shakers and martini glasses behind their backs and under their arms like bar-bound Michael Jordans.
There were the multiple percussionists in the Mixx discoth√®que, incessantly thrumming on giant bongo drums wedged between their knees.
There was the almost-new-car smell of the place.

There were the hundreds of plasma television screens, from the giant ones surrounding the horse-race simulcasting room to the medium-large ones tuned to ESPN in the poker lounge to the wall of miniscreens with lush scenes of frozen drinks and the beach.
But at 11:35 p.m., when the time came to have the big celebrity roll of the first set of dice and the first pull of the slot machine, there was a bit of confusion.
Who -- and where -- were the celebrities?
''Who is that?'' asked one cocktail waitresses, referring to a man in a multicolored cowboy shirt and black 11-gallon hat.
''It's Courtney Cox's husband,'' another cocktail waitress assured her, referring to the man otherwise known as David Arquette.
But no, the craps-throwing celebrity was Stephen Dorff. You remember -- they were both minor characters in the teen-angst sitcom ''Blossom'' in the early 90's.

The initial slot player was Joe Pantoliano, who portrayed an abuser of women and was killed off last season on ''The Sopranos.'' At least Mr. Pantoliano had a New Jersey connection -- the ''Sopranos'' credit and his birth in Hoboken.
''I did it,'' Mr. Pantoliano said to a dozen or so admirers after his third push of the button on the slot machine. ''I won $12.50. It's a great night.''
